channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Robert Towne, Oscar-winning writer of 'Chinatown,' dies at 89
item.description: Robert Towne's script for the 1974 film Chinatown became a model of the art form and helped define the jaded allure of his native LA. His other credits include Shampoo and 1990's Days of Thunder.
item.content:encoded:
Robert Towne's script for the 1974 film Chinatown became a model of the art form and helped define the jaded allure of his native LA. His other credits include Shampoo and 1990's Days of Thunder.

(Image credit: Jim Cooper)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: New presidential immunity ruling goes against what founders intended, scholar says
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Jeffrey Rosen of the National Constitution Center about expanded presidential power in the wake of the Supreme Court's decision in Donald Trump's immunity case.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Jeffrey Rosen of the National Constitution Center about expanded presidential power in the wake of the Supreme Court's decision in Donald Trump's immunity case.
item.dc:creator: Kira Wakeam

item.title: New Mexico village is on alert as devastating flash floods follow June wildfires
item.description: The New Mexico village of Ruidoso is under a flood watch until midnight. This weekend more than 160 people had to be rescued by the National Guard after rains washed debris off hillsides burned in a massive wildfire that started in June.
item.content:encoded: The New Mexico village of Ruidoso is under a flood watch until midnight. This weekend more than 160 people had to be rescued by the National Guard after rains washed debris off hillsides burned in a massive wildfire that started in June.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Coker

item.title: Cyclists get creative to deal with heat during Tour de France
item.description: The Tour de France is cycling's most famous race. But riders are struggling more than ever to manage themselves increasingly intense heat conditions. Here are some of their most innovative strategies
item.content:encoded: The Tour de France is cycling's most famous race. But riders are struggling more than ever to manage themselves increasingly intense heat conditions. Here are some of their most innovative strategies
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda

item.title: A wildlife rehab center has seen a record number of eagles as their population grows
item.description: American eagles have made a remarkable recovery from their low numbers in the 1960s. Now, there are so many, that they compete for habitat with humans and get hurt.
item.content:encoded: American eagles have made a remarkable recovery from their low numbers in the 1960s. Now, there are so many, that they compete for habitat with humans and get hurt.
item.dc:creator: Randi Hagi

item.title: A new federal rule could offer protection from extreme heat to millions of workers
item.description: A proposed rule from the the Occupational Safety and Health Administration would for the first time set in place regulations to better protect workers from extreme heat.
item.content:encoded:
A proposed rule from the the Occupational Safety and Health Administration would for the first time set in place regulations to better protect workers from extreme heat.

(Image credit: Joseph Prezioso)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: Rapamycin is being studied to see if it can slow down age-related diseases in humans
item.description: By testing the drug rapamycin as a way to prevent gum disease — often associated with heart disease and dementia — researchers may learn more about if it slows age-related diseases.
item.content:encoded: By testing the drug rapamycin as a way to prevent gum disease — often associated with heart disease and dementia — researchers may learn more about if it slows age-related diseases.
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: Biggest election year in modern history: Will democracy prevail?
item.description: In this busy year of national elections around the world, NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with election watchers from Ghana, Venezuela and Georgia about how democracy is being challenged where they are.
item.content:encoded: In this busy year of national elections around the world, NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with election watchers from Ghana, Venezuela and Georgia about how democracy is being challenged where they are.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zamora

item.title: Sudan’s civil war continues to pay a heavy toll on the country’s children
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with UNICEF executive director Catherine Russell about her visit to Sudan and what she saw about the toll the country's civil war has had on children.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with UNICEF executive director Catherine Russell about her visit to Sudan and what she saw about the toll the country's civil war has had on children.
item.dc:creator: Elena Burnett

item.title: How Americans feel about their country and its institutions
item.description: We look at how people in the U.S. feel about their country and its institutions, according to NPR polling. In 2003, 70% said they're "extremely proud" to be American. By 2023, it was down to 39%.
item.content:encoded: We look at how people in the U.S. feel about their country and its institutions, according to NPR polling. In 2003, 70% said they're "extremely proud" to be American. By 2023, it was down to 39%.
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro
